serviceName: Get help finding a child arrangement option
printableVersion: View a printable version of the whole guide
phaseBannerText: This is a new service. Help us improve it and give your feedback (opens in new tab).

domesticAbuse.title: Domestic abuse
domesticAbuse.heading: Have you or your children experienced abuse from your ex-partner?
domesticAbuse.intro: You may have been in an abusive relationship if you or your children have experienced any of the following:

bullets.violence: Abuse or violence, including physical, emotional and sexual
bullets.coercive: Coercive control (threats, humiliation, intimidation, degradation, isolation and control)
bullets.childAbuse: Child abuse, neglect, or child abduction

domesticAbuse.error: Select whether you or your children have experienced abuse from your ex-partner

start.title: Get help finding a child arrangement option
start.description: Use this service to find out about your options for making child arrangements if you are a parent separating from your child's other parent.

content.circumstances: You will be asked questions about your circumstances, including your current relationship with your ex-partner.
content.personalDetails: You will not be asked for any personal details and your answers will not be saved or shared with anyone.
content.tenMinutes: It takes about 10 minutes to use this service.

exitTheService.title: If you need to exit the service quickly
exitTheService.description: Each page of this service has an 'Exit this page' button to help keep you safe and protect your privacy if you need it.

content.makingChildArrangements: Making child arrangements if you divorce or separate

content.howToStart: If you are unsure how you can start making child arrangements with your ex-partner, you can get help.

ifYouNeedHelp.title: If you need help deciding how to make child arrangements
ifYouNeedHelp.content: Use the 'Get help finding a child arrangement option' service to find out about your options for making child arrangements if you are a parent separating from your child's other parent.

howItWorks.title: How it works
howItWorks.content:
You will be asked questions about your circumstances, including your current relationship with your ex-partner. You will not be asked for any personal details.

It takes about 10 minutes to use this service.

exitTheService.title: If you need to exit the service quickly
exitTheService.content: Each page of this service has an 'Exit this page' button to help keep you safe and protect your privacy if you need it.

getHelpChildArrangementOption.title: Get help finding a child arrangement option
getHelpChildArrangementOption.content: Your answers will not be saved or shared with anyone.

supportWhenMakingChildArrangements.title: If you need support when making child arrangements
supportWhenMakingChildArrangements.content:
Search for services to help you make child arrangements, including legal aid and impartial advice services.

Find child arrangement support services

contactChildArrangements.title: Are you comfortable contacting your ex-partner about child arrangements?

options.second: No, I am not comfortable contacting them
options.third: No, I do not have their contact details
options.fourth: I can contact them but they do not respond

contactChildArrangements.error: Select whether you are comfortable contacting your ex-partner

agreement.title: Do you and your ex-partner agree on child arrangements?

descriptionList.second: when they spend time with each parent
descriptionList.third: handovers, holidays and whatever else matters to your children

options.first: Yes, we agree on some or most things
options.third: We have not discussed it yet

agreement.error: Select whether you and your ex-partner agree on child arrangements

helpToAgree.title: What would help you both agree on child arrangements?

options.first: A plan we can follow ourselves
options.second: Someone else to guide our conversations
options.third: We cannot agree – someone else needs to make a decision for us

helpToAgree.error: Select what would help you and your ex-partner to agree on child arrangements

otherOptions.title: Have you tried any other options?

content.description: Have you tried any of the following together in the last 6 months?

options.yes: Yes, we have tried one or more of these
options.no: No, we have not tried any of these

otherOptions.error: Select whether you have tried any of these in the last 6 months

courtOrder.title: Explore: Applying for a court order

whyRightForYou.title: Why this could be right for you
whyRightForYou.canApplyIf: You can apply for a court order if:

reasons.cannotAgree: you cannot agree after mediation or getting help another way
reasons.domesticAbuse: there's been domestic or any other kind of abuse
reasons.consentOrder: you're applying for a consent order to make your parenting plan legally binding

orderTypes.childArrangements: child arrangements order, which decides where your child lives and what contact takes place
orderTypes.specificIssues: specific issues order, if you need a decision on a question like what school they go to
orderTypes.prohibitedSteps: prohibited steps order, to stop the other parent from making a decision about the child's upbringing

thingsToConsider.title: Important things to consider
thingsToConsider.mediation: Mediation: You will usually need to show you have tried mediation or another way to agree before you apply for a court order. If you cannot contact your ex-partner, you still need to attend the initial Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM) alone before applying to go to court, unless you are exempt.

miamExemption.warning: You do not have to go to a MIAM if you can show there is a risk:

reasons.life: to your life, freedom, physical safety or home
reasons.unlawfullyTaken: that a child would be unlawfully taken from the UK, or a risk that a child who is currently outside England and Wales will be unlawfully held

miamExemption.moreInfo: If any of these apply, you can apply for an urgent court hearing about child arrangements

thingsToConsider.cost: Cost: It costs £263 to apply for a court order. You may be able to get legal aid to help pay court fees if you're on benefits or a low income.
thingsToConsider.time: Time: It usually takes around 10 months to get a court order, depending on where you live and your situation.

otherWays.title: Other ways to agree without going to court
otherWays.description: Court is the right option for some families. If you want to try another way to agree without going to court, you can look into:

mediation.title: Mediation
mediation.description: This could suit you if: You'd like a professional to help you and your ex-partner agree on the details of a child arrangement. You do not have to be in the same room or video call as your ex-partner.
mediation.inset: You can usually get a voucher worth up to £500 to pay for family mediation through the Family Mediation Voucher Scheme, regardless of what you earn.
mediation.alreadyTried: Already tried mediation? You can always try again, for example if your situation or child's needs have changed.

arbitration.title: Arbitration
arbitration.description: This could suit you if: You'd prefer that someone like a judge or solicitor listens to both of your views and makes a legally-binding decision about the child arrangements.
arbitration.link: Find out more about other ways to agree without going to court

helpAndSupport.title: Help and support
helpAndSupport.description: These are some of the services you may find helpful for applying for a court order.

adviceNow.name: Advice Now
adviceNow.description: Information on what to do before applying for a court order from a charity that provides easy-to-understand information for people facing urgent legal problems.

cafcass.name: Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (Cafcass)
cafcass.description: Advice on the court process from Cafcass, which looks after the interests of children in family court cases in England.

cafcassCymru.name: Cafcass Cymru
cafcassCymru.description: Child-focused advice from Cafcass Cymru, which safeguards children and makes sure their voices are heard in family courts across Wales.

makingArrangements.text: Making child arrangements if you divorce or separate

rightForYou.title: Why this could be right for you

content.chooseAProfessional: Mediation is when you and your ex-partner choose a professional to help you agree on the details of child arrangements.
content.sameRoom: You do not have to be in the same room or call as your ex-partner.

content.info: If you or your children have experienced abuse from your ex-partner, tell the mediator. They can advise on the safest way to continue, or whether you should apply for a court order.
content.initialMeeting: Initial meeting: You may need to go to a short meeting with a mediator to assess if mediation is the right option for you. This is sometimes called a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM).
content.cost: Cost: Mediation is usually cheaper and quicker than going to court. You may be able to get legal aid to cover the cost if you are on a low income. The usual cost of a MIAM is around £120.
content.costInset: You can usually get a voucher worth up to £500 to pay for family mediation through the Family Mediation Voucher Scheme, regardless of what you earn.
content.stayInControl: You stay in control: Unlike in court, where a judge makes the decisions about child arrangements, in mediation you and your ex-partner decide what you agree to and what you don't.
content.childInclusiveMediation: Child-inclusive mediation: Children can have a voice in the process if it's suitable. A mediator can talk to your child about what they want to make sure their views are heard.
content.courtOption: Court is still an option: If the mediator does not think mediation is right for you, they might advise you to go to court instead.

otherWaysToAgree.title: Other ways to agree without going to court
otherWaysToAgree.description: If you want to try another way to agree without going to court, you can look into:

makingAParentingPlan.title: Making a parenting plan
makingAParentingPlan.description: This could suit you if: If you and your ex-partner can agree on child arrangements, you can record it in a child arrangements plan, also called a 'parenting plan'.
makingAParentingPlan.link: Explore: Making a parenting plan

arbitration.title: Arbitration
arbitration.description: This could suit you if: You'd prefer that someone like a judge or solicitor listens to both of your views and makes a legally-binding decision about the child arrangements.
arbitration.link: Find out more about other ways to agree without going to court

helpAndSupport.title: Help and support
helpAndSupport.description: These are some of the services you may find helpful for making child arrangements by mediation.
helpAndSupport.mediationCouncilText: Find a trained mediator from a network of family mediation organisations in England and Wales.
helpAndSupport.legalAidAdviserLink: Find a legal aid adviser or family mediator
helpAndSupport.legalAidAdviserText: Use this service to find legal aid advisers in England and Wales.

content.makingChildArrangements: Making child arrangements if you divorce or separate

optionsNoContact.title: Options to explore if you are not comfortable contacting your ex-partner

content.notComfortable: If you are not comfortable contacting your ex-partner, there are still ways you can make child arrangements without going to court.
content.solicitorCanContact: With these options, your mediator or solicitor can contact your ex-partner for you.

content.attendSession: Shuttle mediation is where you and your ex-partner both attend a session with a mediator, but sit in different rooms or online meetings so you do not have to have any contact.
content.mediatorMoves: The mediator moves between rooms, listening to you both and helping you come to an agreement about child arrangements.
content.getVoucher: You can usually get a voucher worth up to £500 to pay for family mediation through the Family Mediation Voucher Scheme, regardless of what you earn.
content.nextStep: Next step: Find out more about mediation

content.legalAdviser: A family legal adviser can help you negotiate with your ex-partner without going to court. This is known as 'solicitor negotiation' or 'lawyer negotiation'.
content.speakToExPartner: You do not have to speak to your ex-partner if you choose a solicitor to negotiate for you.
content.nextStep: Next step: Find a legal adviser from the Law Society

content.hireLegalAdviser: You and your ex-partner can each hire your own legal advisers to help you negotiate. You then all meet to try and agree on child arrangements.
content.nextStep: Next step: Find out more about collaborative law from Resolution

otherWaysToAgree.title: Other ways to agree without going to court
otherWaysToAgree.description: If you want to try another way to agree without going to court, you can look into:

content.arbitrationText: This could suit you if: You'd prefer that someone like a judge or solicitor listens to both of your views and makes a legally-binding decision about the child arrangements.
content.arbitrationLink: Find out more about other ways to agree without going to court

content.description: These are some of the services you may find helpful for making child arrangements.
content.mediationCouncilText: Find a trained mediator from a network of family mediation organisations in England and Wales.
content.citizensAdviceText: Advice on what to do if your child arrangements aren't working  from a network of independent charities that provides free, confidential and impartial advice online, on the phone and in person.

content.makingChildArrangements: Making child arrangements if you divorce or separate

content.putSmallFiles: The Get help finding a child arrangement service puts small files (known as 'cookies') onto your computer to collect information about how you browse the service.
content.measure: measure how you use the service so it can be updated and improved based on your needs
content.identifyYouPersonally: Get help finding a child arrangement cookies aren't used to identify you personally.
content.messageBeforeStore: You'll normally see a message before we store a cookie on your computer.
content.manageCookiesLink: Find out more about how to manage cookies

howCookiesAreUsed.title: How cookies are used in this service

essentialCookies.title: Essential cookies
essentialCookies.description: Essential cookies are needed for the service to work. We do not need to ask for permission to use them.

rememberingProgress.title: Remembering your progress
rememberingProgress.description: We will store cookies to remember your application progress in this computer and to expire your session after 120 minutes of inactivity or when you close your browser.

valueRow.purpose: Saves your current progress in this computer and tracks inactivity periods
valueRow.expires: After 120 minutes of inactivity or when you close your browser

content.seeBanner: You may see a banner when you visit Get help finding a child arrangement option inviting you to accept or reject optional cookies.
content.setCookies: We'll set cookies so that your computer knows you've seen it and not to show it again, and also to store your settings.

content.googleAnalyticsSoftware: We use Google Analytics software to collect information about how you use Get help finding a child arrangement option. We do this to help make sure the service is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements.
content.howLongYouSpend: how long you spend on each page
content.howYouGotToService: how you got to the service
content.whatYouClick: what you click on while you're visiting the service
content.weDoNotCollect: We don't collect or store your personal information (for example your name or address) so this information can't be used to identify who you are.
content.setsTheCookies: Google Analytics sets the following cookies:

valueRowOne.name: _ga
valueRowOne.purpose: This helps us count how many people visit Get help finding a child arrangement option by tracking if you've visited before

valueRowTwo.name: _ga_
valueRowTwo.purpose: Used by Google Analytics to find and track an individual session with your device

acceptAnalyticsCookies.title: Do you want to accept analytics cookies?

content.reportProblem: To report a problem or suggest improvements to this service, you can email:
content.feedbackEmailAddress: This email address should only be used for feedback on the digital service.
content.cannotAnswerQuestions: We cannot answer any questions about child arrangements.

notFound.title: Page not found
notFound.check: Please check the web address is correct.

generic.title: Sorry, there is a problem with the service
generic.tryReloading: You can try reloading the page or start again.

rateLimit.title: Too many requests have been made
rateLimit.info: The page has been reloaded too many times in a short period.
rateLimit.tryReloading: Please wait a period of 15 minutes, then try reloading the page or start again.

cookieBanner.title: Cookies on Get help finding a child arrangement option
cookieBanner.useEssentialCookies: We use some essential cookies to make this service work.
cookieBanner.useAnalyticsCookies: We’d also like to use analytics cookies so we can understand how you use the service and make improvements.
cookieBanner.acceptedAnalyticsCookies: You have accepted analytics cookies. You can change your cookie settings at any time.
cookieBanner.rejectedAnalyticsCookies: You have rejected analytics cookies. You can change your cookie settings at any time.
